summary_strategy: Reframe summary to emphasize end-to-end ownership of secure, accessible systems for educators/learners—highlighting full-stack delivery (React/TypeScript + backend), CI/CD reliability, and AI-augmented SecOps—while aligning with Instructure’s mission-driven tone
skills_strategy: Use condensed 3-line skills format to maximize relevance: lead with Security Engineering & Automation (prioritizing Python/PowerShell remediation), then Cloud & Platform Integrations (highlighting AWS ECS, Docker, IAM/secrets, CI/CD), and close with Security Data & AI (emphasizing asset correlation, RAG/LangChain, and retrieval tuning—tying to AI tool integration requirement)

experience_focus.must_highlight: end-to-end ownership of secure internal tools, accessibility-aware testing (WCAG), CI/CD reliability, and AI-augmented workflows
experience_focus.safe_metrics_to_keep: 25 percent compliance improvement (from phishing tooling), 200 hours saved annually (certificate automation), 500+ hours reduced workload (distribution list tooling)
experience_focus.claims_to_avoid: no invented metrics, no speculative ownership claims (e.g., 'led' without evidence), no unverified scale numbers beyond source data

risk_controls: Replace all 'built' with 'delivered', 'engineered', or 'developed' to avoid overclaiming; use 'supported' or 'contributed to' where ownership is ambiguous

Never state scale (e.g., 10,000+ devices) without explicit source confirmation—Great Wolf’s 10,000+ is present in resume and retained; UC’s 7,000 endpoints and 2,900-user portal are retained as they appear in baseline
Avoid 'pioneered', 'established the technical standard', or other hyperbolic phrasing—replace with 'delivered', 'operationalized', or 'supported org-wide adoption'
